Answer: The error is because you are trying to use a multicast address with a UDP socket. UDP is a unreliable protocol and does not support multicast. You should use a MulticastSocket instead of DatagramSocket.

<<<api>>>: MulticastSocket
<<<code>>>: MulticastSocket socket = new MulticastSocket(PORT);
<<<explanation>>>: A MulticastSocket is a datagram socket used for sending and receiving datagrams to and from a group of hosts.

Here is the corrected code:

```java
public class UDP {
    public static void main(String args[]) throws IOException {
        InetAddress inetAddress = InetAddress.getByName("239.255.42.99");
        int PORT = 2225;
        int BUFFER_SIZE = 10;
        MulticastSocket socket = new MulticastSocket(PORT);
        byte[] buf = new byte[BUFFER_SIZE];
        String message = "0123456789";
        buf = message.getBytes();
        DatagramPacket datagramPacket = new DatagramPacket(buf, buf.length, inetAddress, PORT);
        socket.send(datagramPacket);
        socket.setSoTimeout(1010);
        socket.close();
    }
}
```

This code will send a datagram packet to the multicast group 239.255.42.99 on port 2225. The message "0123456789" will be sent as a byte array.

Please note that you should also join the multicast group before sending the datagram packet, and leave the group when you're done. You can use the joinGroup() and leaveGroup() methods of the MulticastSocket class for this.

```java
socket.joinGroup(inetAddress);
// send and receive datagrams
socket.leaveGroup(inetAddress);
```

Also, remember to close the socket when you're done with it.

```java
socket.close();
```

This code will work if the multicast group is properly set up on the receiving end. If it's not, you'll need to set up the group on the receiving end first.
